questions.question: What is the difference between Console.WriteLine() and Console.Write() in C#?

options.text: Console.WriteLine() prints text, Console.Write() prints numbers only
options.explanation: Both methods can print any object type.

options.text: Console.WriteLine() adds a newline character after output, Console.Write() does not
options.explanation: WriteLine adds a line terminator (\r\n on Windows), Write outputs without it.
Performance difference is negligible and depends on buffering.

options.text: There is no functional difference between them
options.explanation: The key difference is the automatic line terminator in WriteLine.

questions.explanation: Console.WriteLine() automatically appends Environment.NewLine to the output, while Console.Write() outputs text exactly as provided without adding line terminators.

questions.question: What will this Console.WriteLine() code output when using string interpolation?

options.explanation: This would be the output without the $ prefix.
The $ prefix enables string interpolation, replacing {value} with the variable's value.
String interpolation syntax is valid C#.
String interpolation calls ToString() on the value, not GetType().

questions.explanation: String interpolation (introduced in C# 6.0) uses the $ prefix to embed expressions directly in string literals. The {value} expression is evaluated and converted to string.

questions.question: What will this Console.WriteLine() format string code output?

options.explanation: Composite formatting uses {index:format} syntax with positional arguments.
This would be the literal string without argument substitution.
The F2 format specifier ensures exactly 2 decimal places.
The format string and arguments are properly matched.

questions.explanation: Composite formatting uses numbered placeholders {0}, {1}, etc. The F2 format specifier formats the double with exactly 2 decimal places.

questions.question: What does line 3 output when Console.WriteLine() is called with a null string?

options.explanation: Console.WriteLine doesn't print the literal string 'null'.
Console.WriteLine(null) is equivalent to Console.WriteLine() with no arguments.
Console.WriteLine handles null gracefully.
Console.WriteLine accepts null as a valid argument.

questions.explanation: Console.WriteLine(null) is treated the same as Console.WriteLine() with no arguments, which outputs just a line terminator (empty line).

questions.question: What do lines 2 and 3 output when calling Console.WriteLine() and ToString() on an array?

options.explanation: Arrays don't override ToString() to display elements.
Array.ToString() returns the type name, not the element values.
This would require string.Join() or custom formatting.
The code runs successfully, just doesn't show array contents.

questions.explanation: Arrays inherit the default Object.ToString() behavior which returns the type name. To display array contents, use string.Join() or loop through elements.

questions.question: What does the first Console.WriteLine() call (line 1) output?

options.explanation: This shows the escape sequences as literal text, not interpreted.
\n creates a newline and \t creates a tab character - this is the actual output.
This doesn't show the newline effect.

options.text: Compilation error due to invalid escape sequences
options.explanation: \n and \t are valid escape sequences.

questions.explanation: Escape sequences in string literals are processed at compile time. \n becomes a newline character, \t becomes a tab character.

questions.question: What will Console.WriteLine() output for this boolean expression?

options.explanation: Boolean.ToString() returns 'True' for true values (note the capital T).
C# Boolean.ToString() uses PascalCase, not lowercase.
C# doesn't convert bool to int for string representation.
Boolean.ToString() uses 'True'/'False', not other representations.

questions.explanation: In C#, Boolean.ToString() returns 'True' or 'False' with capital first letters, which differs from some other languages that use lowercase.

questions.question: What happens when using Console.WriteLine() with multiple overloads in this scenario?

options.explanation: The compiler chooses the most specific overload.
WriteLine(int) is more specific than WriteLine(object), so it's chosen.

options.text: Compilation error due to ambiguous method call
options.explanation: The compiler can resolve this based on parameter types.
This would happen if only WriteLine(object) existed.

questions.explanation: C# method overload resolution chooses the most specific applicable method. WriteLine(int) is more specific than WriteLine(object) for an int argument.

questions.question: What will this Console.WriteLine() code output with numeric formatting?

options.explanation: The C format specifier displays currency format with the current culture's currency symbol.
The C format doesn't append 'C' to the number.
This would be the N (Number) format, not C (Currency).
The C format adds currency symbol and proper grouping.

questions.explanation: The C format specifier formats numbers as currency using the current culture's currency format (symbol, decimal places, grouping).

questions.question: What is the behavior of Console.WriteLine() when the console output is redirected?

options.explanation: Console.WriteLine handles redirection gracefully.

options.text: Output is buffered differently and sent to the redirect target
options.explanation: When redirected, console output may be fully buffered instead of line-buffered.
Output is still produced, just sent to the redirect target.

options.text: Behavior is identical to normal console output
options.explanation: Buffering behavior can change when output is redirected.

questions.explanation: When console output is redirected (to file, pipe, etc.), the .NET runtime may change buffering behavior from line-buffered to fully-buffered for better performance.
